fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Some users do not show up on the author list in PR page, regardless of whether they have authored a Pull request or not before on the repository.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
There are no known steps to reproduce this issue at this moment.
This has happened only on certain repositories at this point.

h3. Expected Results
All users that have authored a PR in the past should show up on the PR author list.

h3. Actual Results
Some users are missing from the PR author list. The '?user_search' parameter seems to be malfunctioning on certain repositories.

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Certain users do not show up on the author list in PR page

fields.description:
Currently, the Pull Request activity endpoint does not work with filtering, even though it returns a list of paginated objects.
https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pullrequests/activity

For example, the following request will simply return the list of objects disregarding the updated_on field:
{code}
curl -X GET -u <user>:<pwd> https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/<workspace>/<repoSlug>/pullrequests/activity?q=updated_on+%3C+2020-12-10T00%3A00%3A00-07%3A00&sort=updated_on
{code}

This feature request is to add filtering to this specific endpoint.
fields.summary: PR Activity endpoint API filtering
Large number of files in the downloads sections intermittently fails to load in the UI

fields.description:
This feature request is to allow users to add a button on Bitbucket, on the source page, which allows for web page embedding within Bitbucket.

This will be useful on scenarios such as when users want to manually run builds on alternative CI systems, or to check specific pages right within Bitbucket, instead of needing to go to the website directly.
fields.summary: Allow users to add a button to embed web pages

fields.description:
Currently, the Webhook payload is limited to 256 KB, and the trigger silently fails without an error/notification.
https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/troubleshoot-webhooks/

h4. Use-cases
When users merge a Pull Request, Bitbucket Cloud will include all the commit messages from the Source branch as the new merge commit's message by default.
* If the Source branch has large commit history, the commit messages will be combined and caused the webhook to fail due to a large payload.
* This prevents CI/CD such as Pipelines from triggering Build for large Pull Request
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-21021

h4. Suggestion
It will be best that Bitbucket Cloud support a larger payload
fields.summary: Include ability to trigger Webhook with higher payload

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The names on the "Users on plan" list are listed in alphabetical order, but when the name has an accent or starts with a capital letter, the order is changed
h3. Steps to Reproduce

1. Add users whose names have accents or lowercase and uppercase letters to your plan. Example:
 * Luís
 * Luiz
 * leonardo

2. Open the *Users on Plan* page
h3. Expected Results

The correct order, in this case, should be: 
 leonardo
 Luís 
 Luiz
h3. Actual Results

The names are not showing in the correct alphabetical order
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When the names on "Users on plan" list have accent or start with uppercase or lowercase, the alphabetical order changes
Pipelines endpoint returns invalid URLs for self and steps fields

fields.description:
Currently, the email alias feature is used exclusively to link multiple email addresses within commits back to a specific account.

What customers would like to have is the ability to sign into their Bitbucket account using either their primary email address or any of their aliases.

This would be specifically effective for customers with multiple Atlassian accounts such as accounts created for organizations allowing a better integration on their session between Jira/Confluence and Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Enable email aliases to be used for login purposes

fields.description:
it would be cool as the ONLINE status of the runner is sent to Bitbucket that the same could be done to a service defined to know if the runners are running in StatusPage.

Just add some more variables in the runner entrypoint to configure the parameters:

oAtuth,

Component API ID,

....
fields.summary: Allow bitbucket runner status to be synchronized with Status Page Component

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bitbucket pipeline does not support Hardware acceleration as of now and some users need this to run an emulator for their testing. 

h3. Suggestion
Most android emulators use Hardware acceleration to run tests so it'd be great if the Bitbucket pipeline can support this in the future.
fields.summary: Hardware acceleration support for Bitbucket pipeline

fields.description:
Github now supports rich rendering of jupyter notebooks:

https://github.com/blog/1995-github-jupyter-notebooks-3

It would be great if Bitbucket did as well.  Jupyter notebooks are increasingly used as a format for documentation, sharing computations, and reproducible data science in general.
fields.summary: Enable rich rendering of Jupyter notebooks (BB-12986)

fields.description:
(Suggestion/Bug?) I could not understand how to see commits statistics for repositories, like for example the amount of commits of a user or lines of code which are more persistent, etc..

I saw a similar issue from 2012, i.e. https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-4307?error=login_required&error_description=Login+required&state=ea85730c-282c-4aec-bcb9-fe0ad176c728

It is marked as Closed from 2019, and the Resolution status is "Fixed", but I could not find a way to see these statistics..?

I think seeing commits statistics as: number of commits per user, frequency of commits, persistent lines of code, etc.. These would be valuable information to intuitively show in a panel of a Bitbucket repository
fields.summary: Intuitively display statistics for commits and persistent lines of code in Bitbucket repositories

fields.description:
The documentation page located on the [Bitbucket product page|https://bitbucket.org/product/guides/basics/bitbucket-interface#repositories], mention that we have:
 * On the Your work dashboard you’ll see open pull requests that have you as a reviewer, open pull requests you’ve created, and a list of repositories you can access.

 * Using the filter in the upper-right corner, you can tweak these lists to suit your needs. For example, you might want to hide pull requests with broken builds, so you only see code that’s ready to merge.

We currently can only see the options to:
 * Check your most recent repositories

 * Check the open pull requests that we have access

 * See the Jira Issues linked

We cannot see the Filter option, neither the repository option that shows on the screen share. Can you please consider implement that feature back?
fields.summary: Show the recent activities back on the Dashboard (Your work) page

fields.description:
The pull requests columns sized poorly, makes it impossible to read the information you need on a page.

The title column takes up the majority of the space, and truncates the repository name field making it impossible to read what repistory the PR is for.

It would make far more sense to truncate a really long PR title than the repo name, which is critically important.
fields.summary: Pull requests columns sized poorly

fields.description:
Pipelines test report is unable to identify if the failure is a testcase failure or assertion failure.

Example:

{code:java}
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<testsuites failures="3" errors="0" tests="1">
  <testsuite name="CH.....uage" errors="0" failures="3" hostname="" id="" package="CH.....uage" skipped="0" tests="1" time="39.01" timestamp="">
    <testcase name="......." time="39.01" assertions="7">
      <failure message="1st Failure: ......; (5149ms)">    ..... </failure>
      <failure message="2nd Failure: ......; (5834ms)">    ......</failure>
      <failure message="3rd Failure: ........ (5929ms)">    .........</failure>
    </testcase>
  </testsuite>
</testsuites>
{code}

Pipelines identify the `failures="3"` in the `<testsuites>` as the number of failed `<testcases>`, but their generated test-report is calculated based on the number of "Assertion" failure in the test.

Current Result:  3/1 tests failed
fields.summary: Allow Pipelines to combine/show multiple assertion failures within the same test case

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If you set up pull-requests pipeline, it will trigger a build when you create a Pull Request and you will see a blue icon on the right side of the page showing the in-progress build. However, sometimes we do not see this blue icon even though the build is in progress. Refreshing the page works sometimes. The behavior is inconsistent.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set up the pipeline to trigger on a Pull Request.
 # Create a Pull Request. This will trigger a build and shows a blue icon on the right side of the Pull Request page showing the in-progress build. But sometimes you do not see this blue icon.

h3. Expected Results

The pull requests page should always show the blue icon when there is an in-progress build.

!image-2021-05-14-13-22-57-979.png|width=486,height=84!
h3. Actual Results

Sometimes the pull requests page does not show the blue icon when there is an in-progress build. 
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available. Sometimes refreshing the PR page will show the inprogress build.
fields.summary: Sometimes the Pull request page does not show the builds which are in progress

fields.description:
When I view the Deployment Changes screen in a Monorepo (that has multiple orthogonal deployment streams because it has multiple services), I want to be able to only see the changes that affect the part of the repository that the service (or its dependencies live in):

 !Screen Shot 2021-05-14 at 8.39.34 am.png|thumbnail! 

It would be great if you could either:

# Write subdirectories in your `bitbucket-pipelines.yml` that allowed you to filter down the changes that were shown for a particular deployment.
# In the UI, add in subdirectories that were filtered down.

We want this so that, when we are going to deploy a particular service from a Monorepo, we can see only the changes that will be released by this particular deployment. (Or at the very least, it would be good if we could show some sort of indicator which showed which of the changes will actually be released by this deployment)
fields.summary: Viewing "Deployment changes" in a monorepo should let you filter changes by subdirectories

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
* Syntax highlighting on wiki is broken.
* When used code button on wiki on certain code block, It leaves an extra line with the name of language.
* The extra line with the language name doesn't get removed unless manually removed from wiki.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a wiki page with any code block.
 # Use Code button for syntax highlighting.
# It add the below line on top of the code block. 
{code:java}
#!python
{code}
 !image-2021-05-14-00-57-02-839.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
* The extra line with language name is not supposed to be appearing. 
 !image-2021-05-14-00-58-58-954.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results
!image-2021-05-14-00-57-02-839.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
* Avoid using the code button on wiki and use below triple backticks to achieve syntax highlighting  for any code block as shown below.

{code:java}
```python
def wiki_rocks(text):
    formatter = lambda t: "funky"+t
    return formatter(text)
```
{code}
fields.summary: Code button on wiki adds an extra line with language specifier
Pipelines API endpoint expects a "/" character at the end of its URL

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
PR Comment created outside of the existing PR diff will not mark as outdated after adding the new changes.
(i) This only happens on PR with more than 100 lines of diff in the PR
Demo video: [^Screen Recording 2021-05-13 at 4.07.49 pm-1.mov] 
Sample PR: https://bitbucket.org/r-comm/pr-comment-test/pull-requests/1/

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new branch, then add more than 100 line changes on a single file
# Create new PR
# Add a PR comment outside of the existing PR diff
# Navigate to the source file(under the destination branch)
# Add changes on the same line as the PR comment added earlier
# Refresh PR

(!) Please note that the issue is not reproducible if the PR has less than 100 lines of diff.

h3. Expected Results
Since the file change was added on the same PR comment line, the PR comment should mark as outdated.

h3. Actual Results
The PR comment was not marked as outdated.

h3. Workaround
There's no workaround to mark the PR comment as outdated.
fields.summary: Comment outside of the existing PR diff will not mark as outdated after adding the new changes

fields.description:
*Summary:*
 Currently pipelines doesn't run deployment steps if they are restricted on certain branches when a tag is pushed if a branch restriction is applied on deployments.

*Steps to reproduce:*
 * Configured pipelines to trigger on a tag and execute steps as below.

{code:java}
  tags:
    dvsc-*:
      - step:
          name: Deploytest
          deployment: Staging
          script:
            - echo "Test in tags"
{code}
 * Restricted deployments on staging to be run only from "master" branch using this feature in pipelines under repository settings.
{code:java}
Branches allowed to deploy to Staging:
{code}

 * Pushed a tag to the repository
{code:java}
$ git tag -a dvsc-112       
$ git push --tags
Enumerating objects: 1, done.
Counting objects: 100% (1/1), done.
Writing objects: 100% (1/1), 167 bytes | 167.00 KiB/s, done.
Total 1 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
 * [new tag]         dvsc-112 -> dvsc-112
{code}
Pipelines was triggered on the above repository but it was failed with below message
{code:java}
Paused
This pipeline was paused because Staging can only be deployed to from permitted branch pipelines.
{code}

It was paused because only pushes to master branch are allowed to deploy on staging environment.

*Proposal:*
 Ability to enter tags and tag prefixes along with branches in the below screenshot should help running deployments using tags.

!image-2021-05-12-21-51-09-293.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Allow deployments in pipelines using tags

fields.description:
Summary:
* Currently there is no way to hide the inline comments in the pull requests.
* The available shortcuts are not yet implemented in the new PR UI.
* It is difficult to traverse through the diff view if there are too many comments.
fields.summary: Ability to hide comments in pull requests

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Build start failing with `ActiveStorage::IntegrityError` error while running Ruby on Rails in Pipelines.
This issue happens after pipelines upgrade Kubernetes FlatcarOS to v2765.2.2 on 4th May 2021
[Infrastructure changes in Bitbucket Pipelines |https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/infrastructure-changes-in-bitbucket-pipelines/#:~:text=customer%20builds-,May%202021%20-%20Flatcar,Starting,-on%20May] 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
The smallest test case demonstrating the problem appears to be this ruby script (copied from [docker/for-mac#5570|https://github.com/docker/for-mac/issues/5570])
{code}
require 'fileutils'
require 'tempfile'
tempfile_1 = Tempfile.new(['tempfile_1', ".txt"])
FileUtils.cp('bitbucket-pipelines.yml', tempfile_1.path)
tempfile_2 = Tempfile.new(['tempfile_2', ".txt"])
FileUtils.cp(tempfile_1.path, tempfile_2.path)
puts tempfile_2.read # will be empty, but should not be
{code}
https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/41991#issuecomment-839430133

h3. Expected Results
Rerunning the same succeded build before OS upgrade should show the same outcome

h3. Actual Results
The build failed with following error:
{code}
ActiveStorage::IntegrityError
{code} 

h3. Workaround
Reach out to [support team|https://support.atlassian.com/contact/#/] with the failed Build's URL as we have a temporary workaround for the issue while our infrastructure team working on a permanent solution.
fields.summary: Pipelines build received `ActiveStorage::IntegrityError` error while running Ruby on Rails API

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If Personal WorkspaceID don't match the account username, users will receive Error 404 while trying to delete the LFS file under the workspace

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Navigate to your Personal Workspace Setting and change Workspace ID
https://bitbucket.org/<PersonalWorkspaceID>/workspace/settings
# Navigate to Repository with Git LFS files
# Delete LFS file by navigate to  *Repository Settings>Git LFS* page

h3. Expected Results
LFS file will be removed from the LFS file list

h3. Actual Results
LFS file remain in the list and there's no change on the UI.
(With Browser's developer tools, we will be able to see the request getting `404` status code)

h3. Workaround
* Temporarily change the Personal WorkspaceID to match bitbucket username before delete repo's LFS file, _or_
* Delete LFS files with the following API endpoint
{code}
curl -u <username>:<apppassword> -X DELETE https://api.bitbucket.org/internal/repositories/<WorkspaceID>/<Repo_slug>/lfs/<LFS_oid>
{code}
fields.summary: Unable to delete LFS file after changing Personal WorkspaceID

fields.description:
The RSS Feed from the status page ([https://bitbucket.status.atlassian.com/history.rss)] includes scheduled maintenance items with pubDates in the future. Slacks RSS Feed uses the date as a bookmark and only shows items that appear with pubDates after the previous bookmark. This means the scheduled maintenance posts from the future are hiding current new issues in the feed when viewed from slack.

Slack suggests putting a third party between the above URL and the slack RSS Feed e.g. IFTTT automate.io etc.

I would like to suggest that the feed be modified either to move the scheduled maintenance entries to a new feed specifically for scheduled maintenance or to change the posts so the title includes the date of the maintenance and the pubDate be the actual time of publication of the rss item.
fields.summary: RSS Status Feed

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Unable to migrate issues from Bitbucket Cloud to JIRA

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open: https://bitbucket.org/workspaceid/repository/issues
# Click on "Migrate now"
# Go through the migration

h3. Expected Results
Successful migration

h3. Actual Results

 !image-2021-05-11-12-20-51-625.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

Export the issue from Bitbucket Cloud and import it on JIRA side
fields.summary: Unable to migrate issues from Bitbucket Cloud to JIRA

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Auth session is getting expired on browser close

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open a private repo (https://bitbucket.org/workspace/reposlug)
# Close the browser window
# Re-open the browser
# Copy + paste to access the previously opened private repository

h3. Expected Results
Because of the previously opened session, we can access the repository without any auth process

h3. Actual Results

There's a two seconds gap to authenticate the browser with id.atlassian.com

h3. Workaround

Tick the "Restore previous session"
 !image-2021-05-11-12-04-39-580.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Auth session expires on browser close

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Users unable to clone the annotated tag intermittently with Git shallow clone, such as {{git clone --depth 50}}
This impact CI/CD tools that rely on the commit's tag to complete their deployment.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an annotated tag on the latest commit
{code}
git tag -m "<Tag message>" <Tag>
{code}
# Push the annotated tag with `git push origin <Tag>`
# Clone the repository with `--depth` option
{code}
git clone --depth 50 git@bitbucket.org:<Repo_Slug>
{code}
# Run `git tag --list` command to check the tag list

h3. Expected Results
The latest annotated tag should be included as part of the shallow clone history

h3. Actual Results
The latest annotated tag not listed after running `git tag --list` 

h3. Workaround
* Run "{{git fetch -t}}" to fetch the annotated tag, _or_ 
* Perform a full clone of the repository without "{{--depth}}" option
fields.summary: Unable to clone Annotated Tag with shallow clone intermittently

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Pull request description with a bullet point on JIRA ID caused the text into a new line

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new Pull request
 # Add the following bullet point
{code}
* ST-3 This is a test
* ST-2: This is a test
{code}
 # The output as below example
 !Screenshot 2021-05-11 at 12.55.10 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
The text should be in the same line

h3. Actual Results
The text is moved to a new line

h3. Workaround
No Workaround at this moment, removing bullet point fix the issue
fields.summary: Pull request description with a bullet point on JIRA ID caused the text into a new line

fields.description:
Hey guys,

 

+Background+

I'm an engineer in a company that develops an IDE-like web application that has an integration with Bitbucket using your great API, aimed at our customers who use Bitbucket as their Git provider. A main part of the integration includes our customers selecting a specific repository and a commit, seeing this repo's files tree, and selecting a specific file (either by searching by name or toggling folders to find it).

 

+Problem+

We're using the src resource ([https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/src/%7Bcommit%7D/%7Bpath%7D)] in order to retrieve the files tree of a repo, however, this resource is limited to 100 items (files/directories) per HTTP request, and we find ourselves sometimes make above 100 requests, one by one, in order to retrieve a single repo tree, in a process that can sometimes take 1 minute or even more. In addition, the API does not return any indicator for how big is the repo so we have no idea how many more pages are there to fetch, and we can't indicate to the user anything about the fetching progress, or even decide not to fetch because it's too big before already making dozens of requests to find it out.

While trying to find an alternative solution we examined your search resource ([https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/teams/%7Busername%7D/search/code)] but the fact that it is limited only to the main/master branch of a repo and we can't search in a specific commit made this option irrelevant for us.

This is not a problem we ran into when integrating our web app with any other Git provider, and the situation is that *our customers that use Bitbucket as their Git provider get much worse experience in comparison to others*. In addition, we flood your servers with dozens of requests for fetching just one repo.

 

 

+Suggestions / Requests+:
 # The best solution for us is you guys creating a resource that returns a repo's tree recursively. The only data we really need is the file/folder name and contents. While we researched the issue we found out you actually already got this exact resource in your internal API (https://bitbucket.org/!api/internal/repositories/[project]/[repo_name]/tree/[commit_sha]/?no_size=1). Creating a similar resource in the public API for us to use would be absolutely awesome. This type of resource is something that exists in every other API of a Git provider we tried to integrate to.
 # Adding features to the search resource can also do the trick for us. Searching for matches to a string in a specific commit/branch of a specific repo can enable us to give our customers the best experience using Bitbucket without fetching the whole tree of a huge repository. (Bonus: filter by match type. For example - only path matches, no code matches)
 # That's far from being an ideal solution, but as a minimal help, adding to the existing src resource, next to the 'page' attribute a 'total_pages' attribute, will allow us to at least indicate our customers their progress in the fetching or take a decision in our code to handle the fetching differently.

 

Thanks a lot in Advance :D
fields.summary: Bitbucket API resource for fetching a repository's files tree

fields.description:
When users are unable to accept an invitation to either a repository or group in a workspace, such as when the workspace is at its user limit, the invitation will not get re-sent unless the "resend" button is clicked, even if invitations to other groups or repositories within the same workspace are sent.

At the moment, if the user attempts to accept the invitation they received, even when the invitation acceptance failed, they will be able to access the repository/group on subsequent attempts, if the problem is resolved
The request here is that no further invitations are sent, if invitations to other repositories or groups within the same workspace are not yet accepted. There is no indication that the request is pending on these other groups or repositories, either.

This feature request is to either add a message that shows that the invitation is still pending, or to resend the invitation on each group/workspace.
This will improve user experience, as users need to be aware of basically all groups in order to know when an invitation is pending or not to a given user.
fields.summary: Send additional invitations to user when inviting to a group or repository if initial invitation failed

fields.description:
If you are logging into Bitbucket from a new system, Bitbucket is going to display the following banner:
 !Screen Shot 2021-05-07 at 10.51.15.png|thumbnail! 

The banner message is specifically misleading for existing users which could cause users to believe they have logged in from a new account instead.
fields.summary: Change the banner information for users accessing Bitbucket with an existing account on a different system

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If the customer adds a comment with code it will not highlight the syntax accordingly.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new comment
 # Add code syntax and select the code type
 # Click save
 # It will show the code syntax highlighted for 1 second before removing the highlight
 !Bug.gif! 

h3. Expected Results
* Code syntax should be shown accordingly in the PR comment
h3. Actual Results
* Code syntax is not working in the PR comment

h3. Workaround

We will add a workaround if there is in the future
fields.summary: Pull request comment code syntax highlight not working

fields.description:
Public repositories are currently accessible outside of the IP whitelist. 
If a public repository is created on a private, premium workspace that has the IP whitelisting feature enabled, the repository will still be accessible outside of the IP range.
fields.summary: Make public repositories on workspaces that have IP whitelisting enabled not accessible outside of the IP range

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Pipeline notifications for slack are not being triggered (pipeline successful/pipeline failed/pipeline fixed).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to repository settings
 # On Slack settings, Add subscription
 # Add pipeline notifications in the dropdown (either for a branch or repository-wise)
 # Trigger a pipeline

h3. Expected Results
The pipeline build status would be notified in Slack.
h3. Actual Results
No notifications for pipeline builds are seen in Slack.

h3. Workaround

 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Pipeline notifications for Slack are not being triggered

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

With IP Allow Listing Enabled in Jira Cloud, it shows a 401 Unauthorized error during integration with Bitbucket Cloud

The issue shows up when Bitbucket Cloud is trying to access Jira Cloud as part of the integration process.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Enabled JIRA IP Allowlisting in Jira Cloud instance
 # Perform the Bitbucket Cloud and Jira Cloud integration.
 ** Perform the integration from Bitbucket Cloud.

h3. Expected Results
 * Integration goes through successfully.

h3. Actual Results
 * 401 Unauthorized error is shown at the JIRA URL with this endpoint " /secure/BitbucketPostInstallApprovalAction.jspa"
 ** !screenshot-5.png|width=347,height=213! 
h3. Workaround
 * The only possible workaround currently is to disable JIRA IP Allow listing
fields.summary: Bitbucket Cloud DVCS Integration with Jira produces 401 error with JIRA IP Allow Listing Enabled

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If login session expired, Bitbucket Cloud doesn't redirect to login page while user trying to access Workspace's list of repository page.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open incognito browser
# Access the list of repositories link with the following URL:
_Sameple: https://bitbucket.org/<WorkspaceID>/workspace/repositories_
# Bitbucket Cloud will prompt with "That link has no power here" page without any redirection to the login page

h3. Expected Results
It's expected that the Repository list page will work the same as the private repository, which will check the login session and redirect to the login page.

h3. Actual Results
The repository page shows "That link has no power here" page instead of redirecting to the login page
 
h3. Workaround
From the "That link has no power here" page:
# Click the "dashboard" text to allow Bitbucket Cloud to redirect to login page
# Once it's logged in, user can try to access the Project page again
fields.summary: Accessing Workspace's Repository page does not redirect to login page

fields.description:
This feature request is to have the functionality to send reminders to pull request reviewers for long-overdue pull requests.

Bitbucket Server has this plugin. [https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1212840/reminders-for-bitbucket?hosting=server&tab=overview]
fields.summary: Send reminders to pull request reviewers

fields.description:
h3. Summary:
The Bitbucket integration in Jira only looks at the first 100 commits in a pull request. Therefore if there are more than 100 commits in a PR, those commits are ignored in the JIRA issues view.

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this issue.
fields.summary: Bitbucket integration in Jira only looks at the first 100 commits in a pull request

fields.description:
It would be great to have a simple way to export this git diff into an HTML file to send to a non-git user. Looking for something I can send from a power user to a newbie dev who just needs to see line changes.

*Workaround(ish)*
Currently, you can use the "Compare" feature in a repository and share the URL to another user (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51116069/how-to-compare-two-commits-in-bitbucket). However, the other user should have access to the repo to be able to see it (if the repo is private), and this would not be a simplified version for an inexperienced dev or non-git user.
fields.summary: Ability to export Git diff into HTML

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Repository's initial commit doesn't update repo the 'Main branch' which causes the 'Commit', the 'Branch' and the 'Pull Requests' pages redirect you back to the Source page
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a repository with API or create a repo through UI(exclude README and .gitignore)
 # From the new repo's Source page, click `Create a README` or `Create a .gitignore` button to create a default initial commit
 # Click 'Commit', 'Branch' or 'Pull Requests' from the left navigation bar

h3. Expected Results

You are redirected to 'Commit', 'Branch' or 'Pull Requests' pages.
h3. Actual Results

You will be redirected to the Source page. 
h3. Workaround
 # Navigate to *Repository Settings* > *Advanced* section
 # Update the *Main branch* field
 # Refresh the repo page
fields.summary: Repository's initial commit doesn't update repo 'Main branch' which causes the 'Commit', 'Branch' and 'Pull Requests' pages redirect back to Source page

fields.description:
I'm sending an email message for some pipelines using an after-script clause, and the email-notify pipe. To avoid repeating all the details of email sending, I use yaml anchors, but I'd like to customize the email message to identify the pipeline that failed. The end result is currently something like this:
{code:java}
definitions:
  .send_email_def: &send_email_on_fail
    after-script:
      - if [[ $BITBUCKET_EXIT_CODE == 0 ]]; then false; else true; fi #only continue if build actualy failed
      - pipe: atlassian/email-notify:0.4.3
        variables:
          USERNAME: $SMTP_USER
          PASSWORD: $SMTP_PASSWORD
          FROM: $SMTP_USER
          TO: 'some-user@example.com'
          HOST: 'smtp.gmail.com'
          PORT: 587
          SUBJECT: "Pipeline $BITBUCKET_DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT"

pipelines:
  custom:
    pipeline1:
      - step:
          deployment: pipeline1
          script:
            - #some commands
          <<: *send_email_on_fail{code}
Whereas I define a test deployment environment named "pipeline1".

Obviously this is an abuse of the deployments feature, and even if it weren't, This type of customization belongs in the source code, not in the Bitbucket project metadata.

I was thinking of something like:
{code:java}
definitions:
  .send_email_def: &send_email_on_fail
    after-script:
      - if [[ $BITBUCKET_EXIT_CODE == 0 ]]; then false; else true; fi #only continue if build actualy failed
      - pipe: atlassian/email-notify:0.4.3
        variables:
          USERNAME: $SMTP_USER
          PASSWORD: $SMTP_PASSWORD
          FROM: $SMTP_USER
          TO: 'some-user@example.com'
          HOST: 'smtp.gmail.com'
          PORT: 587
          SUBJECT: "Pipeline $PIPELINE_NAME"

pipelines:
  custom:
    pipeline1:
      - step:
          variables:
            PIPELINE_NAME: "pipeline1"
          script:
            - #some commands
          <<: *send_email_on_fail
{code}
(All this is just a concrete example, I'd like to customize yaml anchors not just for setting the pipeline name but to give parameters to build scripts as well. The key point is to to be able to set a variable per-step via bitbucket-pipelines.yml and not via deployments)
fields.summary: Set environment variables per step via bitbucket-pipelines.yml

fields.description:
As a user of ABC "Atlassian Bitbucket Cloud" with several hundred users on our team, it would be great to have basic usage reports by user, eg last login date, commit/PR activity by repo/project, member of group level reporting out of the tool.  

 

Thanks!
fields.summary: Usage Reports

fields.description: I wanted to investigate whether it's possible for Bitbucket to force-merge, overriding settings in `Branch permissions`. This can useful in cases where an emergency PR or hotfix needs to be implemented.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Cloud support Force Merge overriding Branch Permissions

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Using the UI, it is possible to create a PR with an attachment or to add an attachment to an existing PR.

This is currently not possible when using the REST APIs.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the following features via APIs:
- add attachments as part of the PR creation API
- add attachments to an existing PR
fields.summary: As a developer using the REST APIs, I want to be able to create a PR with attachments and add attachments to an existing PR

fields.description:
Currently, sweeping branch permissions prevent creation of a scheme in which all branches have some (light) restrictions, some branches identified specifically have more permissive permissions, and some branches identified specifically have more _restrictive_ permissions.

Example:

branches:
 * production
 * staging
 * wip/feature-one
 * jr/feature-two

Permissions:
 * {{*}} can be written only by senior devs (allowing arbitrary {{wip,bugfix,whatever}} from senior devs)
 * {{jr/*}} can be written by junior devs (forcing jr devs to label their branches as such)
 * {{staging}} can only be modified by PR (no write)
 * {{production}} can only be modified by PR (no write)

Under current overlapping rules, senior devs would be able to directly push to {{staging}} and {{production}} by virtue of the wildcard rule.

Many workarounds exist (require *everyone* to follow certain branch naming rules), but it would nonetheless be extremely helpful to have something as simple as a checkbox to explicitly state permissions from other patterns should *not* apply to a given branch/ruleset.
fields.summary: Ability to explicitly prevent overlapping positions

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
With the current limitation to our webhook service. Merging a pull request with a large commit message fails to trigger an automatic build. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure bitbucket-pipelines.yml file to trigger a build when a pull request is merged to target branch
# Open a pull request with a large commit message (e.g. 4K lines)
# Merge the pull request

h3. Expected Results
* Upon merging the pull request a build should automatically trigger on the target branch
* Customers should be notified that the payload is too large and has failed to trigger an automatic build. Doing so will provide a better experience overall. At the moment, there is no indication of what a build was not triggered when customers expect a build to trigger automatically. 

h3. Actual Results
* Build is not triggered on the target branch 
* No indication into why the build was not triggered automatically 
* This is caused by "Webhook payload is limited to 256 KB. Webhooks may silently fail to trigger if their payload is too large." - Reference: [Troubleshooting webhooks|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/troubleshoot-webhooks/]

h3. Workaround
Manually trigger build on the branch: Navigate to the "Branches" page,  then click on the triple dots (...) at the end of the branch, and then "Run pipelines for a branch".
fields.summary: When a commit message is large on a pull request Pipeline build not triggered

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Even if users have access to any personal workspace (outside of their own personal workspace), users will not be able to use the Code Search functionality on those workspaces.
The dropdown to select the workspace on the Code Search page will not show personal workspaces, only shared workspaces and the personal workspace of the currently logged-in user.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Get access to any personal workspace (the workspace that is created automatically under your account when you create it) outside of your own personal workspace
 # Go to Code Search
 # Click on the dropdown to select the workspace - You will be unable to see it there.

h3. Expected Results
All workspaces that the user has access to must show up on code search.

h3. Actual Results
Personal workspaces do not appear on Code Search's dropdown.

h3. Workaround
There are two workarounds here:
1. Go directly to the following URL, switching the UUID for the UUID of the workspace that you want to search for:
{code}
https://bitbucket.org/search?account=%7B<UUID>%7D
{code}

2. Move the repositories from the personal workspace to a shared workspace. This will take some work, but it doesn't require the use of any workaround afterwards.
fields.summary: Code Search does not include personal workspaces

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When creating a new repository and adding a value to the field "Default branch name", the repository will still show the text on the next page:

{code}git remote add origin git@bitbucket.org:workspacename/repositoryname.git
git push -u origin master{code}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new repository and add a value to the field "Default branch name"
 # Don't include a README nor .gitignore file
 # Click on Create repository
 # Bitbucket will redirect you to the Source page on this repository 
 # Under "Get your local Git repository on Bitbucket", it will show you the following instructions: 

Step 1: Switch to your repository's directory

{code}cd /path/to/your/repo{code}
Step 2: Connect your existing repository to Bitbucket

{code}git remote add origin git@bitbucket.org:carolineroos/hello.git
git push -u origin master{code}

h3. Expected Results
Update the branch name to the one the user has created 

h3. Actual Results

The command still shows the word 'master' 

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When creating a repository and adding a value to the field "Default branch name", Bitbucket will still show the word 'master' under the instructions

fields.description:
Hi. Is it possible to restrict specific repository or user by IP address? (Rather than entirely at an account level)

Use case - we are working with a new external agencies to help us out and we may want to restrict backend code for security and regulatory reasons.

 

Thanks.
fields.summary: Restrict repository or user by IP address

fields.description:
As per the title, this feature request is to add the ability to remove any inactive authors from the Pull request author list in Bitbucket.

This can be a toggle setting, as there may be users that would not like to see the users that no longer have access to their repositories in the authors dropdown.
fields.summary: Remove inactive authors from the PR author list

fields.description:
Currently if you go to Pull Requests Settings there is an option for what you want shown for differences in the files included in the pull request.  One of the options is `Whitespace changes".  This currently does not ignore carriage returns.  Could you either modify this to include carriage returns or add an option for `carriage returns` that would now show them?

Thanks!
fields.summary: Pull Request Settings

fields.description:
*This is a request for the option to allow users to Add Language to the list of Programming Language.*

If it's not possible to make the list dynamically extendable, then at least prefill the available options with the base languages, such as from this [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_programming_languages|list of programming languages].

Reasoning:

It is practical to be able to add the language of a repository - however, the current list isn't representative of the languages in use across the industry. The current list is also a mix of languages and IDE's, which does not cover all cases.

Just today I wanted to add Pic Basic Pro, which is of course a BASIC dialect, but the language BASIC is not an option and none of the specialized BASIC dialects would fit.

The same is true for Microchip UC8, UC16, and UC31 compilers, and many, many more. In fact just our small site uses more than 20 specific compilers that are not covered by the current list.

Note: This request is an extension of BCLOUD-3676  (which specifically targets PowerBASIC).
fields.summary: Request to allow users to Add Language to the list of Programming Language

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
On the Pull requests page, if the user loads a PR that displays one of the following messages:
 !Screen Shot 2021-04-28 at 17.33.38.png|thumbnail! 
 !Screen Shot 2021-04-28 at 17.33.32.png|thumbnail! 

Whenever the user loads another PR that should not display this error message, the same message from the previous Pull Request will be displayed instead.

At the time of writing, I was only able to reproduce this issue with the messages above, but I will expand this bug report in case new messages are found to cause this problem

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open a pull request that returns a "Something Went Wrong" or "Nothing to merge" message
# Click on the "Pull Requests" tab to go back to the main PR page
# Open any other pull request whose diff should load properly
# The same message from the first PR will be displayed instead of the actual diff.

h3. Expected Results
The diff properly loads regardless of which PR was previously opened.

h3. Actual Results
The diff will display the same error message from the previously opened PR.

h3. Workaround
Reload the page. The diff will load correctly.
fields.summary: Opening a second pull request when a PR has a message on it will not allow the diff to load

fields.description:
"Diff" is a language option when writing a code blocks in pull request descriptions and comments. However, Bitbucket does not color the +/- lines as it does with real file diffs.

For an example, see this pull request: [https://bitbucket.org/jennings/pr-diff-test/pull-requests/1]

In this PR, the real file diff that Bitbucket generates is highlights +/- lines in green/red, but the code blocks in my description and comments are not highlighted. I did set the language to "Diff" before saving them.

I believe this is *not* a duplicate of BCLOUD-8673 or BCLOUD-9238, because those tickets are want to see syntax highlighting for the language like C# or Python inside file diffs.
fields.summary: Code blocks with language "Diff" should be highlighted like file diffs

fields.description:
Some of the users would like to get the list of the repositories/PRs that doesn't have reviewer assigned in order to approve a branch to be merged to master branch

It would be a useful feature, if we were have a functionality where we could see if there are any PRs without reviewer.
fields.summary: Being able to find pull requests without reviewers

fields.description: The branch page shows a list of commits, and the number of commits the branch is behind the destination branch. It would be useful to also see a count of the commits in the branch. I rebase branches and I like to validate the commit counts shown by `git status` after the rebase. Having the branch page show a count of the commits in the branch will help with that validation.
fields.summary: Show count of commits in a branch

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Having more than a certain number of repositories will not allow the group page to load.
Currently, the threshold to trigger this bug seems to be ~8700 repositories, but it could be smaller.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have 8700+ repositories on a single workspace
 # Create a group with 5-10 people in it
 # This group will keep timing out.

h3. Expected Results
The group's page loads correctly regardless of the number of repositories

h3. Actual Results
The group's page times out

h3. Workaround
The workaround at this moment is to navigate to the following page:
https://bitbucket.org/<workspace>/workspace/settings/groups/<groupName>?privilege=write 
You can then click on the "Members" tab to open it up, and it should load correctly
fields.summary: Having more than a certain number of repositories does not allow groups to load (BAM-298)

fields.description:
At the moment, it is not possible to use Git LFS in the Wiki of a Bitbucket Cloud repo.

It has been requested that we add support for Git LFS in wikis as well.
fields.summary: Support Git LFS in Wikis

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Updating the username of a workspace adding capital letters on the workspace settings page is not allowed. 
"Workspace IDs can only contain lowercase letters, numbers, dashes, and underscores."
However, if you create a new account, the new account can have a username with capital letters on it.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to workspace settings
 # Change the name to something with Capital letters

h3. Expected Results
You would be able to change the username of a workspace back to the original value (with Capital letters)
h3. Actual Results
You are prevented from adding Capital letters to the username of a workspace. 

h3. Workaround

 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Updating the username of a workspace adding capital letters on the workspace settings page is not allowed.

fields.description:
Ability for users who have pre-defined scripts to have an option in Pull Request API to tag a specific user (not the one whose credential is used on the API) as the Author of the Pull Request while create a pull request using this API:

https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pullrequests#post
fields.summary: Pull Request API update to allow a custom user setting

fields.description:
Ability to customise the name of test reporting and the other tabs in Pipelines Build logs, such as Docker, Artifact etc. 

Currently multiple tests are under a single tab, it would be better if each test is on a different tab. 

Additionally, it would also be useful to be able to customise the names of the different tabs in build logs.
fields.summary: Customise Test Reporting Pipelines Tab and other Tabs

fields.description:
Bitbucket Pipelines supports user-provided variables: [https://bitbucket.org/blog/adding-human-interaction-back-into-automated-builds]

However, despite what that page suggests, those variables currently cannot be used in the 'deployment' field. If I try to do this:
{code:java}
custom:
  deploy-to-any-env:
    - variables:
      - name: ENVIRONMENT
    - step: 
        deployment: $ENVIRONMENT
        script: ...
    {code}
Then I get this error:

!image-2021-04-26-10-39-12-521.png!

Therefore, if I have multiple deployment environments and I want to write a custom pipeline that deploys to one of them, I have to actually write many custom pipelines, one per target deployment environment.

Please consider allowing variables in the 'deployment' field.
fields.summary: Allow the use of variables in the 'deployment' field of a BB Deployment

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
You are able to commit without issue keys in the message via PR from a forked repository to a repo that has the "Require issue keys in commit messages" enabled. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Enable the "Require issue keys in commit messages" option in a repository 
 # Fork this repo 
 # Do not enable the "Require issue keys in commit messages" option in the forked repository 
 # Commit any changes in the forked repository without adding any issue key in the message 
 # Create a Pull Request without any issue key and, in the destination branch field, select a branch from the original repository 
# Merge the Pull Request  

h3. Expected Results
You shouldn't be able to create a PR to the repository that has the "Require issue keys in commit messages" enable if you don't have an issue key in your commit

h3. Actual Results
You are able to merge the PR without any issue keys in the commit message into a repository that has the "Require issue keys in commit messages"  option enabled 

h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: You are able to commit without issue keys in the message via PR from a forked repository to a repo that has the "Require issue keys in commit messages" enabled

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Side panel disappears intermittently on PR when committing new changes
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Create a new PR
 * Commit and push a new change
 * Reload the PR page right after pushing
 * The side panel disappears
 * This issue does not occur every time, it is intermittent

h3. Expected Results
 * After reloading the page, the side panel is loaded

h3. Actual Results
 * After reloading the page, the side panel disappears (intermittently)

h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Side panel disappears intermittently on PR when committing new changes

fields.description:
Right now, if you have a pull request with an outdated comment and you clicked that comment from the *Activity* tab, the page will show the pop-up with the updated comment, however, it is slow.

*Enhancement:*
It would be really helpful if we could improve the loading time when clicking an outdated comment from the PR's *Activity* tab.
fields.summary: Pull request activity tab pop-up slow loading

fields.description:
Currently, the speed while accessing the *Bitbucket.org* website or specifically working through pull requests is significantly slower.
 * 5-8 seconds for loading pull request list
 * 14-20 seconds for loading a pull request with images as comments

*Enhancement:*
 It would be greatly appreciated if we could improve pull requests website interaction performance specifically from Taiwan and Japan.
fields.summary: Improve Bitbucket.org website performance accessing from Taiwan and Japan

fields.description:
Currently, when diffs time out when attempting to load due to exceeding the diff limits (see https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/limits-for-viewing-content-and-diffs), we show a "something went wrong" error message.

This feature request is to have a specific error message stating that the diff limit has been reached, and this is the reason why the diff did not load.
fields.summary: Show friendlier message for large diffs that exceed the diff limits

fields.description: Currently, all Bitbucket cloud infrastructure is hosted with NTT in the US at the Ashburn, VA, and Santa Clara, CA locations. It'd be great if the user is able to select which data center they wish to store their data since some customers might have security requirements on their data storage location.
fields.summary: Ability to select which region to store Bitbucket cloud data

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Rapidly selecting a non-default pipeline from the "Run a pipeline from a branch" dropdown available in the "branches" page changes the selected pipeline back to the default/first one.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to branches page
 # Click the action button (...) right side of the branch
# Select "Run pipeline for a branch"
# Check what is the default pipeline selected
# Close the page
# Reopen the "Run pipeline for a branch" rapidly selecting a non-default pipeline


h3. Expected Results
The pipeline selected from the dropdown is kept
h3. Actual Results
The pipeline selected gets rolled back to displaying the default pipeline

h3. Workaround

# Wait until the page is completely loaded before selecting a pipeline.
# Use the "Run pipeline" from the pipeline tab as it seems to be unaffected by this behavior.
fields.summary: Selecting a non-default pipeline from the "Run a pipeline from a branch" dropdown changes the selected pipeline back to the default

fields.description:
Update members API end point to show the date/time when a user was added to a workspace
https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/workspaces/%7Bworkspace%7D/members
fields.summary: Update Members API end point with Date/Time of addition

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
It would be a useful feature if the "Require two-step verification" could be enabled/disabled using Rest API or if the status (if it's enabled or disabled) could be queried,

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Allow to show the status or Enable/Disable the "Require two-step verification" (Access Control feature) using REST API

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Customers are intermittently unable to add reviewers while creating a new pull request

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In a repository, create a new PR
# Add users as reviewers

h3. Expected Results
The drop-down search will find all team members you wanted to review your PR

h3. Actual Results
The drop-down search couldn't find all the team members you wanted to review your PR

h3. Workaround

Use an API 2.0 endpoint to add reviewers to an existing pull request.
*Step 1:*
Use this [API endpoint|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/users/%7Busername%7D] to identify the UUID of the person/user you wanted to add as a reviewer
{code:java}
curl -X GET -u username:appPassword https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/users/<WORKSPACE_ID>/members
{code}

*Step 2:*
Once the user/person's UUID is identified, prepare the payload by running the command below:
{code:java}
printf '{ "title": "Some title of the PR here", "reviewers": [{ "uuid": "{replace_me_with_an_actual_uuid}"}]}' > payload
{code}

*Step 3:*
Use the below API endpoint to update the existing pull request.
{code:java}
curl -X PUT -u 'username:password' https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/{owner}/{repo_slug}/pullrequests/{pullrequest_id} -d @payload --header "Content-Type: application/json" -v
{code}
(i) If your account is managed by your organization with SSO. Kindly generate an App password first and use it as your password for authentication. - [App Passwords|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/app-passwords/]

(i)To find out your <WORKSPACE_ID> from step 1, click on your avatar > Select your workspace > Settings > Workspace settings. The workspace ID can be found in the "workspace ID" field. It should also be in the URL of your workspace, like so:
{code}
https://bitbucket.org/<WORKSPACE_ID>/
{code}

h3. Workaround

Clear all cookies for https://bitbucket.org and try to use the search/dropdown again.
fields.summary: Unable to add users as reviewers in a PR intermittently

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Users are getting the same error code - 403 while trying to download a 2GB archive compares to have invalid access.
Hence, it's not possible for users to distinguish the differences between repo is too large or its invalid credential with the same error code - 403

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # With Browser's developer tools(Network) open, download public 2GB archive by navigating to Repo's Download page:
 #* https://bitbucket.org/mirror/linux/downloads/?tab=branches
 # Then, download 2GB archive from a private repository to which the account do not have access:
 #* Sample link: https://bitbucket.org/r-comm/linux/get/master.tar.gz

h3. Expected Results
User expect both failures to return different exit code

h3. Actual Results
Both failures return the same exit code - 403, which is hard for third-party tools to distinguish what's the actual root cause of the issue.

h3. Workaround
No workaround
fields.summary: Download >2GB archive return the same error code as invalid repo access

fields.description:
Currently, it is possible to run a build leveraging the following endpoint:
/2.0/repositories/{workspace}/{repo_slug}/pipelines/

https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pipelines/

However, for manual steps, there is no specific endpoint to trigger them via API.
Imagine that for this manual step to run we need to have the necessary approval based on an external change management system.

With the currently available features, It is only possible to trigger a new build which would generate a new build ID and start the process all over
Or manually trigger the deployment via UI.
fields.summary: Create an endpoint to trigger specific/manual step for Pipeline Builds

fields.description:
Kindly update the permission end point to cover details regarding  when a user was added/changed permission etc.
https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/workspaces/ivzdso/permissions/repositories/<repo-slug>

Or a new endpoint to retrieve this data.
fields.summary: Update Permission endpoints with update data

fields.description:
This feature request is to enable users to enforce a specific main branch name to all repositories under a given workspace.
This would allow users to better keep track of the names used in the workspace, and will allow users to use the name "main" by default as their main branch instead of "master"
fields.summary: Enforce main branch name to a custom name

fields.description: In addition to the 'like' button for comments, it would be nice to have an option to 'like' an entire PR.
fields.summary: 'Like' button for PRs

fields.description:
This feature request is to add the ability to delete all pipelines builds on a given repository, in order to allow users to start over, when required

At this moment, the only workaround is to push the repository all over again to Bitbucket, which is not very viable since you would lose all of your metadata.
fields.summary: Ability to delete all Pipelines builds for a given repository

fields.description:
Currently, the owner of the snippet or the workspace admin cannot delete a comment on the snippet. 

As per our [API doc|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/snippets/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Bencoded_id%7D/comments/%7Bcomment_id%7D], only the author of the comment can delete the snippet comment.

This feature request is to allow the snippet owner to delete comments on the snippet.
fields.summary: Allow snippet owner to delete comments on the snippet.
Allow mounting volumes outside $BITBUCKET_CLONE_DIR in Bitbucket pipelines
Currently we are unable to add multiple kind entries while adding a branch restriction using POST

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bitbucket.org favicon is not working on the Chrome browser.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to [https://bitbucket.org/]
 # Notice the tab icon

!bitbucket.org_favicon.png|width=483,height=117!
h3. Expected Results

The favicon on Chrome will show
h3. Actual Results

The favicon on Chrome is not showing

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Bitbucket.org website favicon is not working on Chrome browser

fields.description: It would be great if it was possible to just update your authenticator app within your Bitbucket's 2SV and Atlassian Account 2FA without the need to actually disabling it and re-enabling.
fields.summary: Ability to update MFA apps without the need to disable/enable again

fields.description:
Currently manual deployment steps of pipelines expire after 14 days with the note "Artifacts have expired". At UltimateAI we tested if this problem can be avoided with deployment steps that does not depend on any artifacts and have the explicit artifacts download flag set to false. Even with this setting BBPL the manual deployment step is unavailable with same notice. Here is our test pipeline: [https://bitbucket.org/%7B62c8f407-f945-4567-93de-a8c60921ec0e%7D/%7B056f5d14-2a62-4055-9905-598d5b5f78a6%7D/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/4049]

 

"Old" pipelines are important, often for the rollback purposes. Could you please enable deployment steps that does not depend on artifacts even after the 14 days limit?
fields.summary: Deployment Steps That Does Not Depend On Artifacts Should Not Expire

fields.description: This feature request is to allow forking from external sources outside of Bitbucket, and allow features such as syncing.
fields.summary: Forking from external sources

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The Code search feature on Bitbucket cloud is giving an inconsistent result while searching with certain substrings of a file name.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In a repository, create a file with the name "*_TestFileConnectionWhenContext_Builder.java*"
 # Go to the repository *Source* tab
 # Use the Code search feature by clicking the (+) icon on the left side of the repository
 # Search the following substring:
 ** TestFileConnectionWhenContext = {color:#57d9a3}Found 1 file{color}
 ** TestFileConnectionWhenContextBuilder = {color:#57d9a3}Found 1 file{color}
 ** TestFileConnectionWhenContextBuild = {color:#de350b}*No result*{color}

h3. Expected Results

Searching using substrings of a file name is working
h3. Actual Results

Searching using substrings of a file name is _not_ working

h3. Workaround
Search files locally using a 3rd party code editor
fields.summary: Searching file with certain substrings in Code Search has an inconsistent result

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If a Pipelines build is still running in the background and it hit the max build time limit (e.g. using *max-time* config), the total time it takes to run the script doesn't match the total step execution time.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

In a repository with Pipelines enabled, copy the configuration below and run a Pipeline build
 * 
 ** 
{code:java}
image: atlassian/default-image:2

pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: 'Test'
        max-time: 2
        script:
          - sleep 5m
          - echo "done"
{code}

h3. Expected Results

The scripts/commands total time are matched with the total step execution time
h3. Actual Results

The scripts/commands total time are _not_ matched with the total step execution time

*Result:*
 !pipelines_execution_time.png|width=548,height=240!
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Pipelines scripts execution time is not match to the total step time
Ability to add README's and .gitignore files in the repo creation through 2.0 API

fields.description:
At this time, pulling a private image from ECR in the build step requires the 'AWS' section to provide secret/access keys.

Additional support of OIDC for authentication would be a great addition to this.
fields.summary: OpenID Connect support for private build image in ECR

fields.description: I don't know how when i deployment k8s with deployment file in my computer only 32s but we run pipeline with step apply deployment in Bitbucket pipeline we need 5m, so how we can optimize it.
fields.summary: Pipeline apply to my system very slow in pipeline

fields.description:
Recently MacOS Mojave improved and expanded the dark mode and it was promoted heavily in media. Many apps followed, introducing dark mode option in their interfaces.

BitBucket interface should also offer a dark mode - the pure white backgrounds look jarring against the latest dark wallpapers and dark toolbars and dark Chrome's menu bars.

!3860899609-dark_mode.png|thumbnail!

Let's add a new feature which would let BitBucket customers switch to a dark UI.

It could be a simple _toggle switch_ somewhere in the sidebar, for example:

!2375479882-toggle.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Dark mode for the BitBucket UI

fields.description:
+Steps to reproduce:+
 # Navigate to your repo pipelines page
 # Expand the schedule menu tab 
 # Notice that the menu screen is way too small to easily read and comfortably manage the scheduled runs 

 ** The column text gets truncated at 13 characters 
 ** Horizontal and vertical scrollbars showing for a tiny window that makes it very difficult to interact with
 ** Users need to inspect the column text in order to see the full description

 

+Expected results:+

There are so many ways how this can be resolved. Here are a few suggestions:
 * Allow full-screen view - a simple table/list will do
 * Allow users to dynamically adjust the menu size 

 

+Additional comments:+
 * It's extremely frustrating when you need to find a specific schedule run among multiple runs. Something that supposes to take a few seconds can take 30 min. 
 * Test run lists should NOT be managed via the menu windows that are meant for static list of menu items and not lists that are constantly evolving and being edited
fields.summary: Pipelines | Schedules menu | Increase menu size

fields.description:
While the page is loading the merge status, the approve/needs work buttons are showing and clickable, but right when it finishes loading the status, it shifts the buttons so the approve button is where the needs work button is, and it causes a lot of accidental approvals. These views should not change position like that when it finishes loading.

More detail:

https://photos.app.goo.gl/224bu9TtFBbxjFRu6
fields.summary: Merge button loading causes approve/needs work button to shift, causing mis approvals

fields.description:
Controls not present/Issue: Atlassian has provided two weeks timelines for fixing of critical patches which is not in line with Fidelity requirements.

Business Impact: A patch management process ensures that the production infrastructure is suitably protected against the rise of widespread worms and malicious code targeting known vulnerabilities on unpatched systems. There is a risk that these open vulnerabilities might be exploited by an individual or organised crime groups and ascertain Fidelity Confidential information resulting in financial and reputational repercussions.

Recommendation: Atlassian should ensure that critical patches are deployed within 72 hours.
fields.summary: Deployment of critical patches for bitbucket and Jira-Confluence cloud.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The merge check "Atleast 1 successful build and no failed builds" is checking for all the builds on the source branch.

If there are two PRs with the same source branch and different destination branch, and if the build fails for one of the PR, the merge check on the other PR prevents merging the PR even though the build for this PR is successful.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a 'develop' branch.
 # Configured pipelines YAML to run on pull requests on develop branch.
 # Create the 'release/v0.1' from develop branch.
 # Added a new commit to the 'develop' branch.
 # Created the 'release/v0.2' branch from 'release/v0.1' branch
 # Added a new commit on ''release/v0.2'' branch on the same line as above commit on 'develop'
 # Create a pull request PR-1 to merge branch 'release/v0.2' to 'release/v0.1'. The pipelines build will be successful.
 # Create a pull request PR-2 to merge branch 'release/v0.2' to 'develop'. This PR will have a merge conflict as per the commits based step 4 and step 6. The pipelines build will fail due to the merge conflict.
 # Configure branch Branch permissions on the develop branch and set "Check the last commit for at least 1 successful build and no failed builds" and "Prevent a merge with unresolved merge checks"
 # Due to the above branch permission, the first PR is not allowed to be merged because of the failed build on the second PR which has the same source branch.

h3. Expected Results

Merge check should allow merging the first PR because the build for this PR is successful.
h3. Actual Results

Merge check prevents merging the first PR because of the failed build on the second PR which has the same source branch.
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: The merge check "Atleast 1 successful build and no failed builds" is checking for all the builds on the source branch

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The merge check "Atleast 1 successful build and no failed builds" is checking for all the builds on the source branch.

If there are two PRs with the same source branch and different destination branch, and if the build fails for one of the PR, the merge check on the other PR prevents merging the PR even though the build for this PR is successful.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a 'develop' branch.

 # Added a new commit to the 'develop' branch.

 # Added a new commit on ''release/v0.2'' branch on the same line as above commit on 'develop'
 # Create a pull request PR-1 to merge branch 'release/v0.2' to 'release/v0.1'. The pipelines build will be successful.
 # Create a pull request PR-2 to merge branch 'release/v0.2' to 'develop'. This PR will have a merge conflict as per the commits based step 4 and step 6. The pipelines build will fail due to the merge conflict.
 # Configure branch Branch permissions on the develop branch and set "Check the last commit for at least 1 successful build and no failed builds" and "Prevent a merge with unresolved merge checks"
 # Due to the above branch permission, the first PR is not allowed to be merged because of the failed build on the second PR which has the same source branch.

h3. Expected Results

Merge check should allow merging the first PR because the build for this PR is successful.
h3. Actual Results

Merge check prevents merging the first PR because of the failed build on the second PR which has the same source branch.
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: The merge check "Atleast 1 successful build and no failed builds" is checking for all the builds on the source branch
Old workspace name is shown as the author of PRs and commits

fields.description:
Issue Summary
"*next*" param which will have the link to the next page results is not showing up in deployments API - /2.0/repositories/{workspace}/{repo_slug}/deployments/


Expected Results
If the number of deployments are more than the default pagelen -10, then the json response should include a "next" param with a URL

Actual Results
"*next*" param which will have the link to the next page results is not showing up 

Workaround
append /?page=1, /?page=2 and so on until the result is null.
fields.summary: deployments API - "next" param is not showing up

fields.description:
Please add current file number on review of a large pull request. We can't see how many files are still remaining to be reviewed on a large pull request (since we can only view one file at a time).

Maybe it can be added before the < > buttons.
fields.summary: Show current file number on the review of a large pull request
